questions.question: 1. In a DSB-SC modulation scheme, which of the following statements is correct about the spectrum of the modulated signal?

answers.a: The spectrum consists of two sidebands with the carrier frequency in the center.
answers.b: The spectrum consists of a single sideband with the carrier frequency in the center.
answers.c: The spectrum consists of the carrier frequency and its two sidebands.
answers.d: The spectrum consists of the carrier frequency only.

explanations.a: The spectrum of a DSB-SC signal has two sidebands around the carrier frequency, but no carrier.
explanations.b: This describes an SSB-SC modulation, not DSB-SC.
explanations.c: This description fits amplitude modulation, not DSB-SC.
explanations.d: A DSB-SC signal does not have a carrier frequency component.

questions.question: 2. What is the main advantage of SSB-SC modulation over DSB-SC modulation?

answers.a: SSB-SC modulation has higher bandwidth efficiency.
answers.b: SSB-SC modulation requires less power for transmission.
answers.c: SSB-SC modulation has better noise immunity.
answers.d: SSB-SC modulation is simpler to implement than DSB-SC.

explanations.a: SSB-SC modulation is more bandwidth efficient because it transmits only one sideband.
explanations.b: While SSB-SC may require less power for transmission, this is not its primary advantage.
explanations.c: SSB-SC and DSB-SC have similar noise immunity characteristics.
explanations.d: SSB-SC is generally more complex to implement compared to DSB-SC.

questions.question: 3. How is the carrier signal used in the demodulation of a DSB-SC signal?

answers.a: The carrier signal is needed at the receiver to recover the original message signal.
answers.b: The carrier signal is not needed for demodulation; only the modulated signal is required.
answers.c: The carrier signal is used to filter out the sidebands.
answers.d: The carrier signal is used to amplify the modulated signal.

explanations.a: The carrier signal is essential for coherent detection of a DSB-SC signal to recover the original message.
explanations.b: The carrier is crucial for the demodulation process in DSB-SC.
explanations.c: Carrier signal is not used for filtering sidebands but for mixing.
explanations.d: Amplification is not the role of the carrier signal in demodulation.

questions.question: 4. In Single Sideband Suppressed Carrier (SSB-SC) modulation, how is the message signal typically reconstructed?

answers.a: By mixing the received signal with a local oscillator that has the same frequency as the carrier used in modulation.
answers.b: By filtering out the unwanted sideband from the received signal.
answers.c: By using an envelope detector to extract the message signal.
answers.d: By direct demodulation without any further processing.

explanations.a: Reconstruction requires mixing with a local oscillator to retrieve the original message signal.
explanations.b: Filtering out the sideband is not sufficient; mixing is required.
explanations.c: Envelope detection is not suitable for SSB-SC as it requires coherent detection.
explanations.d: Direct demodulation is not feasible without additional processing in SSB-SC.

questions.question: 5. Which of the following best describes the phase relationship between the message signal and carrier in DSB-SC modulation?

answers.a: The message signal and carrier are in phase.
answers.b: The message signal and carrier are out of phase by 90 degrees.
answers.c: The phase relationship is irrelevant in DSB-SC modulation.
answers.d: The message signal and carrier are out of phase by 180 degrees.

explanations.a: In DSB-SC modulation, the message signal modulates the carrier without affecting its phase.
explanations.b: Phase relationship is not a key aspect of DSB-SC modulation.
explanations.c: The phase relationship is crucial for coherent detection but not specified in modulation.
explanations.d: The phase relationship is not inherently fixed at 180 degrees.

questions.question: 6. Which filter type is typically used to extract the original message signal from an SSB-SC signal?

explanations.a: Band-pass filters are used in SSB-SC to recover the message signal from the modulated signal.
explanations.b: Low-pass filters are not suitable for extracting the message signal from SSB-SC.
explanations.c: High-pass filters are not appropriate for SSB-SC signal extraction.
explanations.d: Band-stop filters are used for eliminating specific frequencies, not for SSB-SC extraction.

questions.question: 7. In DSB-SC modulation, how is the amplitude of the carrier signal affected by the modulation process?

answers.a: The amplitude of the carrier signal is suppressed or removed.
answers.b: The amplitude of the carrier signal increases proportionally with the message signal.
answers.c: The amplitude of the carrier signal remains unchanged.
answers.d: The amplitude of the carrier signal is modulated in a manner similar to amplitude modulation.

explanations.a: In DSB-SC modulation, the carrier signal's amplitude is suppressed; only the sidebands carry the information.
explanations.b: The carrier's amplitude is not directly affected but suppressed in the final signal.
explanations.c: The carrier's amplitude is not unchanged but suppressed.
explanations.d: The carrier is suppressed, not modulated in amplitude in DSB-SC.

questions.question: 8. What is the key difference between DSB-SC and SSB-SC in terms of bandwidth usage?

answers.a: DSB-SC uses twice the bandwidth of SSB-SC.
answers.b: SSB-SC uses twice the bandwidth of DSB-SC.
answers.c: DSB-SC and SSB-SC use the same bandwidth.
answers.d: Bandwidth usage depends on the modulation index of the signal.

explanations.a: DSB-SC has twice the bandwidth of SSB-SC because it includes both sidebands.
explanations.b: SSB-SC is more bandwidth efficient compared to DSB-SC.
explanations.c: The bandwidth of DSB-SC is double that of SSB-SC.
explanations.d: Bandwidth difference is not dependent on modulation index.

questions.question: 9. In an SSB-SC signal, what happens to the carrier frequency?

answers.a: The carrier frequency is completely removed from the signal.
answers.b: The carrier frequency is present but at a reduced amplitude.
answers.c: The carrier frequency is modulated along with the message signal.
answers.d: The carrier frequency is used for phase modulation of the message signal.

explanations.a: The carrier is removed or suppressed in SSB-SC, leaving only one sideband.
explanations.b: The carrier is suppressed or not present in SSB-SC.
explanations.c: Carrier frequency is not present in SSB-SC.
explanations.d: Phase modulation is not related to SSB-SC as carrier is suppressed.

questions.question: 10. In a DSB-SC system, how is the demodulated signal obtained?

answers.a: By multiplying the received signal with a locally generated carrier signal.
answers.b: By directly filtering the received signal with a low-pass filter.
answers.c: By using an envelope detector on the received signal.
answers.d: By applying a frequency demodulator to the received signal.

explanations.a: Demodulation in DSB-SC involves multiplying the received signal with a locally generated carrier of the same frequency.
explanations.b: Filtering alone is not sufficient for demodulation; multiplication with a carrier is needed.
explanations.c: Envelope detection is not suitable for DSB-SC as it requires coherent detection.
explanations.d: Frequency demodulation is not used for DSB-SC signals.

questions.question: 11. Which property of SSB-SC modulation makes it preferable for long-distance communication compared to DSB-SC?

explanations.a: SSB-SC's higher bandwidth efficiency allows it to transmit more information over the same bandwidth.
explanations.b: Power consumption is not the primary advantage of SSB-SC.
explanations.c: Both SSB-SC and DSB-SC have similar resistance to interference.
explanations.d: SSB-SC demodulation is generally more complex than DSB-SC.

questions.question: 12. What is the main disadvantage of using DSB-SC modulation compared to other modulation schemes?

answers.a: DSB-SC requires a higher bandwidth than SSB-SC.
answers.b: DSB-SC is more vulnerable to noise and interference.
answers.c: DSB-SC requires more power to transmit.
answers.d: DSB-SC is more complex to implement than other modulation schemes.

explanations.a: DSB-SC uses twice the bandwidth of SSB-SC because it transmits both sidebands.
explanations.b: Both DSB-SC and SSB-SC are vulnerable to noise; DSB-SC has the disadvantage of using more bandwidth.
explanations.c: Power consumption is not the primary disadvantage of DSB-SC.
explanations.d: DSB-SC is simpler to implement compared to SSB-SC.
